title: The new Covid variant NB.1.8.1 is driving infections in Australia. A virologist explains what you need to know | Lara Herrero for the Conversation
snippets:
Evidence so far suggests NB.1.8.1 may spread more easily and partially sidestep immunity from prior infections or vaccination

  • Australia news live: latest politics updates

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

As we enter the colder months in Australia, Covid is making headlines again, this time due to the emergence of a new variant: NB.1.8.1.

Last week, the World Health Organization designated NB.1.8.1 as a “variant under monitoring”, owing to its growing global spread and some notable characteristics which could set it apart from earlier variants.

Continue reading...
titles: The new Covid variant NB.1.8.1 is driving infections in Australia. A virologist explains what you need to know | Lara Herrero for the Conversation
summary: The new COVID-19 variant, NB.1.8.1, is gaining attention as it may spread more easily and evade immunity from past infections or vaccinations. The World Health Organization has labeled it a "variant under monitoring" due to its increasing global presence and distinct characteristics. This development comes as Australia enters its colder months, with a noticeable rise in infections linked to this variant.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about a new Covid-19 variant, informing readers about its characteristics and potential impacts. However, it does not discuss any solutions or improvements related to the issue.

title: Watch These HP Price Levels as Stock Tumbles After Company Cuts Outlook Due to Tariffs
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • HP shares fell sharply Thursday after the company missed analysts’ profit expectations and issued a light outlook, citing increased costs from tariffs. 
  • Thursday’s decline followed a breakdown from a rising wedge pattern in yesterday's trading session.
  • Investors should watch important support levels on HP's chart around $25, $23 and $21, while also monitoring a key overhead area near $29.


HP (HPQ) shares plunged Thursday after the PC maker missed analysts’ profit expectations and issued a light outlook, citing increased costs from tariffs.

The PC maker said its guidance reflects tariff costs and actions taken to mitigate associated trade risks, adding that it had responded quickly to expand its manufacturing footprint and reduce its cost structure. CEO Enrique Lores said during the earnings call that additional tariff costs "could not be fully mitigated in the quarter," and that HP has "implemented price increases to help offset cost pressure."

HP shares fell more than 8% Thursday, posting the biggest declines in the S&P 500. The stock has lost nearly a quarter of its value so far in 2025 as investors assess the cost of the company’s ongoing efforts to diversify its supply chain while it navigates the Trump administration’s unpredictable trade policies.

Below, we take a closer look at HP’s chart and use technical analysis to identify price levels worth watching out for.

Rising Wedge Breakdown

Since bottoming out early last month, HP shares have staged a countertrend rally, forming a rising wedge pattern in the process.

In an ominous sign, the stock broke down below the pattern’s lower trendline on above-average volume in Wednesday’s trading session ahead of the company’s quarterly report, paving the way for a continuation move lower.

It’s also worth pointing out that the relative strength index has recently fallen below the 50 threshold, signaling weakening price momentum.

Let’s identify three important support levels to watch and also locate a key overhead area worth monitoring during future upswings.

Important Support Levels to Watch

The first lower level to watch sits around $25, right about where the stock closed on Thursday. This area may provide support near a brief period of consolidation within the rising wedge pattern and the prominent September 2023 trough.

A move below this level could see HP shares fall to the $23 region. The price may attract support here near the low of the stock’s first minor dip after bouncing from its early-April low.

Selling below this level opens the door for the shares revisiting lower support at $21. Investors may seek longer-term buy-and-hold entry points in this area near last month’s tariff-driven low.

Key Overhead Area Worth Monitoring

During future upswings in the stock, investors should monitor the $29 area. A recovery effort into this region would likely meet overhead resistance near the rising wedge pattern’s peak, which also closely aligns with a temporary pause in the stock’s downtrend during March.

The comments, opinions, and analyses expressed on Investopedia are for informational purposes only. Read our warranty and liability disclaimer for more info.

As of the date this article was written, the author does not own any of the above securities.
titles: Watch These HP Price Levels as Stock Tumbles After Company Cuts Outlook Due to Tariffs
summary: HP's shares fell over 8% on Thursday, marking significant declines after the company reported earnings below analysts' expectations and provided a weak financial outlook, attributed to increased costs from tariffs. This downturn followed a technical pattern breakdown, suggesting potential further declines. HP is adjusting its pricing and supply chain to mitigate tariff impacts but has seen its stock value drop nearly 25% in 2025 amid challenges from the Trump administration's trade policies. Key support levels for HP's stock are identified at $25, $23, and $21, with significant overhead resist
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about HP's stock performance and its response to tariff impacts. It also identifies key support levels for the stock, which could be actionable for investors. However, it doesn't report on any solutions or improvements.

title: Scientists Discover Violation of 1931 Thermodynamic Principle
snippets: The cell model of ion-exchange membranes reveals violations of the Onsager reciprocity principle, particularly at high electrolyte concentrations, highlighting the importance of accounting for asymmetric transport coefficients. Ion-exchange membranes are widely used in electrochemical and separation processes, and accurate modeling of their transport properties is essential. A new study published in the journal Asymmetry demonstrates [...]
titles: Scientists Discover Violation of 1931 Thermodynamic Principle
summary: Scientists have discovered a violation of the Onsager reciprocity principle, a fundamental thermodynamic principle established in 1931, in ion-exchange membranes, particularly at high electrolyte concentrations. This finding, detailed in the journal Asymmetry, underscores the need for accurate modeling of these membranes' transport properties, which are crucial in various electrochemical and separation processes. The study highlights the importance of considering asymmetric transport coefficients in the modeling of ion-exchange membranes.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information and deeper understanding about a new scientific discovery, which challenges a long-standing principle. However, it does not clearly highlight solutions or progress, nor does it offer actionable insights.

title: Turning Waste Into Energy: New Enzyme Revolutionizes Biofuel Production
snippets: The natural protein, known as CelOCE, was developed at the Brazilian Center for Research in Energy and Materials and is ready for immediate integration into industrial processes. Breaking down plant material into usable fuel has long been one of science’s biggest energy challenges. At the heart of this process is cellulose, the most abundant renewable [...]
titles: Turning Waste Into Energy: New Enzyme Revolutionizes Biofuel Production
summary: Researchers at the Brazilian Center for Research in Energy and Materials have developed a new enzyme, CelOCE, that significantly enhances biofuel production by efficiently breaking down cellulose, the most abundant renewable biomass material. This breakthrough allows for the conversion of waste into usable energy, marking a major advancement in biofuel technology. CelOCE is ready for immediate industrial application, promising to revolutionize the biofuel industry by making the process more efficient and sustainable.
constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights an innovative solution in the field of biofuel technology. It provides actionable insights for industries and contributes to the reader's understanding of advancements in renewable energy.

title: Long shot science leads to revised age for land-animal ancestor
snippets: The fossils of ancient salamander-like creatures in Scotland are among the most well-preserved examples of early stem tetrapods -- some of the first animals to make the transition from water to land. Thanks to new research, scientists believe that these creatures are 14 million years older than previously thought. The new age -- dating back to 346 million years ago -- adds to the significance of the find because it places the specimens in a mysterious hole in the fossil record called Romer's Gap.
titles: Long shot science leads to revised age for land-animal ancestor
summary: Scientists have discovered that fossils of ancient salamander-like creatures found in Scotland, initially believed to be significant examples of early stem tetrapods transitioning from water to land, are 14 million years older than previously thought, dating back to 346 million years ago. This new dating places the specimens within Romer's Gap, a mysterious period in the fossil record, thereby enhancing the importance of the find in understanding early terrestrial animal evolution.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides readers with a deeper understanding of the evolution of terrestrial animals. It reports on the significant discovery and its implications for our understanding of a mysterious period in the fossil record, thereby contributing to the reader's knowledge and awareness of the subject.

title: Listening to electrons talk
snippets: Researchers present new experimental and theoretical results for the bound electron g-factor in lithium-like tin which has a much higher nuclear charge than any previous measurement. The experimental accuracy reached a level of 0.5 parts per billion. Using an enhanced interelectronic QED method, the theoretical prediction for the g-factor reached a precision of 6 parts per billion.
titles: Listening to electrons talk
summary: Researchers have achieved a significant milestone in the measurement of the bound electron g-factor in lithium-like tin, marking a notable improvement in experimental accuracy to 0.5 parts per billion. This work examines elements with a higher nuclear charge than those previously studied. Additionally, the team utilized an advanced interelectronic Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) method to predict the g-factor with a theoretical precision of 6 parts per billion, showcasing a substantial advancement in the field's understanding and measurement capabilities.
constructiveness_reason: The story is constructive as it reports on an innovation in the field of Quantum Electrodynamics. It offers useful insights into the advanced techniques used for predicting the g-factor with a high degree of precision. While the topic might be complex for some readers, it still contributes to the understanding of advancements in the field.
